DOCNAME: CASE OF FRANCESCO SESSA v. ITALY [Extracts]
CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;No violation of Article 9 - Freedom of thought conscience and religion (Article 9-1 - Manifest religion or belief)
JUDGES: András Sajó;Françoise Tulkens;Guido Raimondi;Helen Keller;Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Paulo Pinto De Albuquerque
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . The applicant is NORP and a lawyer by profession . On DATE he appeared before the ORG investigating judge at a hearing concerning a request for the immediate production of evidence ( “ incidente probatorio ” ) in his capacity as representative of CARDINAL of the CARDINAL complainants in criminal proceedings against several banks . The investigating judge in charge of the case was prevented from sitting and his replacement invited the parties to choose CARDINAL dates for the adjourned hearing DATE either CARDINAL or DATE already identified by the investigating judge .

CARDINAL . The applicant pointed out that both dates coincided with NORP religious holidays ( DATE and GPE respectively ) and stated that he would be unable to attend the adjourned hearing because of his religious obligations . He explained that he was a member of the GPE NORP community , and alleged a breach of sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL of DATE governing relations between the ORG and ORG NORP communities .
CARDINAL . The investigating judge set the hearing down for DATE .

CARDINAL . DATE the applicant lodged an application with the investigating judge in charge of the case to have the hearing adjourned . On DATE , after examining the application , the judge decided to add it to the case file without ruling on it .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a criminal complaint against the investigating judge in charge of the case and his replacement , alleging that they had breached section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL of DATE . DATE he informed ORG about the complaint .

CARDINAL . At the hearing of DATE , the investigating judge noted that the applicant was absent for “ personal reasons ” and asked the parties to express their views on the application for an adjournment made on DATE . The prosecution and counsel for the defendants objected to the application , arguing in particular that it was not based on any of the statutory grounds for adjournment . However , counsel for the other complainant supported the applicant ’s request .

CARDINAL . NORP In an order issued the same day the investigating judge rejected the application for an adjournment . He noted at the outset that , under LAW of LAW , only the prosecution and counsel for the defendant were required to be present at hearings concerning the immediate production of evidence ; the presence of counsel for the complainant was optional . He went on to observe that LAW did not oblige the judge to adjourn a hearing where counsel for the complainant had legitimate reasons for being unable to appear . Lastly , he stressed that a large number of individuals were involved in the proceedings ( the defendants , the complainants , court - appointed experts and experts appointed by the parties ) and that , “ in view of the heavy workload of the office , which would [ have meant ] adjourning the hearing until DATE , the application , submitted by an individual with no legitimate reason to request an adjournment , ha[d ] to be rejected in accordance with the principle that cases should be heard within a reasonable time ” .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the applicant that it was not competent to examine the matter since the applicant ’s complaints related to the exercise of judicial activity .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE , the PERSON public prosecutor ’s office had requested that no further action be taken on the applicant ’s complaint . The applicant objected to this request on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the PERSON investigating judge made an order discontinuing the proceedings concerning the applicant ’s complaint , noting that the applicant had not objected to the request for no further action submitted by the public prosecutor ’s office .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal on points of law , complaining of the investigating judge ’s failure to take account of the objection he had lodged on DATE . ORG , observing that the failure to take the applicant ’s objection into account had probably been due to a registry error , set aside the order of DATE and referred the case back to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant and the prosecution attended a hearing before the PERSON investigating judge . On DATE the latter issued an order discontinuing the proceedings . He noted that there was nothing in the case file to suggest that the investigating judge in charge of the case or the judge who had replaced him at the hearing of DATE had had any intention of infringing the applicant ’s right to practise his NORP faith freely or of offending the applicant ’s dignity on account of his religious faith .

CARDINAL . Law no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE contains provisions governing relations between the ORG and ORG NORP communities . LAW the right to practise and manifest the NORP religion freely . Under section CARDINAL , GPE grants persons of NORP faith who so request the right to observe the Sabbath , in the context of flexible working arrangements and without prejudice to the requirements of the essential services provided for by the ORG legal system .
Section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL states that DATE , GPE and other NORP religious holidays are to be treated in the same way as the Sabbath .

CARDINAL . According to the fifth paragraph of LAW , manifestations of religious intolerance and prejudice are punishable by the penalties provided for in LAW CARDINAL of PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE , which is the PERSON ratifying LAW of all Forms of Racial Discrimination . Under the latter provision , anyone who disseminates ideas based on superiority or on racial or ethnic hatred , or incites others to commit acts of racial , ethnic , national or religious discrimination , is liable to a prison sentence of DATE .
CARDINAL . The first paragraph of LAW , which governs the procedure for the immediate production of evidence ( “ incidente probatorio ” ) reads as follows :
“ The hearing shall take place in private . The public prosecutor and counsel for the defendant shall be required to attend . Counsel for the injured party shall also have the option of attending . ”
